@@ -5,11 +5,11 @@
 
 The great churches of Kievan Rus', built after the [[Baptism of Kievan Rus'|adoption of Christianity]] in 988, were the first examples of monumental architecture in the East Slavic lands. The architectural style of the Kievan state which quickly established itself was strongly influenced by the [[Byzantine architecture|Byzantine]]. Early [[Eastern Orthodox]] churches were mainly made of wood with the simplest form of church becoming known as a [[cell church]]. Major cathedrals often featured scores of small domes, which led some art historians to take this as an indication of what the pagan Slavic temples should have looked like.

+The 10th-century [[Church of the Tithes]] in Kiev was the first cult building to be made of stone.  The earliest Kievan churches were built and decorated with [[fresco]]es and [[mosaic]]s by Byzantine masters. 
 
 Another great example of an early church of Kievan Rus' was the thirteen-domed [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Kiev]] (1037–54), built by [[Yaroslav the Wise]]. Much of its exterior has been altered with time, extending ove the area and eventually acquiring 25 domes. 
 
-[[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Novgorod]] (1044–52) {{source?|date=June 2012}}, on the other hand, expressed a new style that exerted a strong influence on Russian church architecture. Its austere thick walls, small narrow windows, and helmeted cupolas have much in common with the [[Romanesque architecture]] of Western Europe. 
+[[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Novgorod]] (1044–52) {{citation needed|date=June 2012}}, on the other hand, expressed a new style that exerted a strong influence on Russian church architecture. Its austere thick walls, small narrow windows, and helmeted cupolas have much in common with the [[Romanesque architecture]] of Western Europe. 
 
 Even further departure from Byzantine models is evident in succeeding cathedrals of Novgorod: St Nicholas's (1113), St Anthony's (1117–19), and St George's (1119).
 
@@ -19,7 +19,6 @@
 
 [[File:Bogolyubovo.jpg|thumb|100px|[[Church of the Intercession on the Nerl]] (1165), one of the most famous Russian medieval churches.]]
 By the end of the 12th century the divide of the country fas final and new centers of power took the Kievan style and adopted it to their traditions. In the northern principality of [[Vladimir-Suzdal]] the local churches were built of white stone with help of Romanesque masters of [[Friedrich Barbarossa]], whilst their wall statuary was elaborately carved by craftsmen from [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]].{{Citation needed|date=May 2008}} The Suzdal style is also known as "white-stone architecture" ("белокаменное зодчество"). The first white-stone church was the [[St. Boris and Gleb Church]] commissioned by [[Yuri Dolgoruky]], a church-fortress in [[Kideksha]] near Suzdal, at the supposed place of the stay of knyazes Boris and Gleb on their pilgrimage to Kiev. The white-stone churches mark the highest point of pre-[[Mongol invasion of Rus|Mongolian]] Rus' architecture. The most important churches in [[Vladimir]] are the [[Assumption Cathedral in Vladimir|Assumption Cathedral]] (built 1158-60, enlarged 1185-98, frescoes 1408) and [[St Demetrios Cathedral]] (built 1194-97).
-
 
 In the western splnter of [[Kingdom of Halych-Volhynia]] churches in a traditional Kievan style were built for some time, but eventually the style began to drift towards Central European Romanesque tradition.

Another miraculously preserved church is the graceful [[Intercession Church on the Nerl]] (1165), one of the most charming images of medieval Russia. 

Celebrated as these structures are, the contemporaries were even more impressed by churches of Southern Rus, particularly the Svirskaya Church of [[Smolensk ]](1191-94). As southern structures were either ruined or rebuilt, restoration of their original outlook has been a 
source of contention between art historians. The most memorable reconstruction is the Pyatnitskaya Church in [[Chernigov]] (1196-99), by [[Peter Baranovsky]].

Secular architecture of [[Kievan Rus]] is scarcely known. Up to the 20th century, only the [[Golden Gate (Vladimir)|Golden Gates]] of [[Vladimir]], despite much 18th-century restoration, could be regarded as an authentic monument of pre-Mongolian period. In the 1940s, the archaeologist [[Nikolai Voronin]] discovered the well-preserved remains of [[Andrei Bogolyubsky]]'s palace in [[Bogolyubovo]], dating from 1158-65.

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -1,7 +1,7 @@
 The medieval state of '''[[Kievan Rus']]''' incorporated parts of what is now modern [[Ukraine]], [[Russia]], and [[Belarus]], and was centered on [[Kiev]] and [[Novgorod]]. Its '''architectural style''' quickly established itself after the [[Baptism of Kievan Rus'|adoption of Christianity]] in 988 and was strongly influenced by the [[Byzantine architecture|Byzantine]]. After the disintegration of [[Kievan Rus']] followed by [[Mongol invasion of Rus|Mongol invasion]] in the first half of the 13th century, the architectural tradition continued in the principalities of [[Novgorod Republic|Novgorod]], [[Vladimir-Suzdal]], [[Galicia-Volhynia]] and eventually had direct influence on the [[Russian architecture|Russian]], [[Ukrainian architecture|Ukrainian]], and [[Belarusian architecture|Belarusian]] Architecture.
 
 ==Church architecture==
-[[File:Maket Sofii.JPG|thumb|200px|Before its reconstruction in the 18th century, St. Sofia in Kiev was a prime example and a model for all churches in Kievan Rus]]
+[[File:Maket Sofii.JPG|thumb|300px|Before its reconstruction in the 18th century, St. Sofia in Kiev was a prime example and a model for all churches in Kievan Rus]]
 
 The great churches of Kievan Rus', built after the [[Baptism of Kievan Rus'|adoption of Christianity]] in 988, were the first examples of monumental architecture in the East Slavic lands. The architectural style of the Kievan state which quickly established itself was strongly influenced by the [[Byzantine architecture|Byzantine]]. Early [[Eastern Orthodox]] churches were mainly made of wood with the simplest form of church becoming known as a [[cell church]]. Major cathedrals often featured scores of small domes, which led some art historians to take this as an indication of what the pagan Slavic temples should have looked like.
 
@@ -17,7 +17,7 @@
 
 The 12th-13th centuries were the period of feudal division of Kievan Rus into princedoms which were in nearly permanent feud, with multipication of cathedrals in emerging princedoms and courts of local princes ''[[knyaz]]es''.
 
-[[File:Bogolyubovo.jpg|thumb|100px|[[Church of the Intercession on the Nerl]] (1165), one of the most famous Russian medieval churches.]]
+[[File:Bogolyubovo.jpg|thumb|300px|[[Church of the Intercession on the Nerl]] (1165), one of the most famous Russian medieval churches.]]
 By the end of the 12th century the divide of the country was final and new centers of power took the Kievan style and adopted it to their traditions. In the northern principality of [[Vladimir-Suzdal]] the local churches were built of white stone with help of Romanesque masters of [[Friedrich Barbarossa]], whilst their wall statuary was elaborately carved by craftsmen from [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]].{{Citation needed|date=May 2008}} The Suzdal style is also known as "white-stone architecture" ("белокаменное зодчество"). The first white-stone church was the [[St. Boris and Gleb Church]] commissioned by [[Yuri Dolgoruky]], a church-fortress in [[Kideksha]] near Suzdal, at the supposed place of the stay of knyazes Boris and Gleb on their pilgrimage to Kiev. The white-stone churches mark the highest point of pre-[[Mongol invasion of Rus|Mongolian]] Rus' architecture. The most important churches in [[Vladimir, Russia|Vladimir]] are the [[Assumption Cathedral in Vladimir|Assumption Cathedral]] (built 1158-60, enlarged 1185-98, frescoes 1408) and [[St Demetrios Cathedral]] (built 1194-97).
 
 In the western splinter of [[Kingdom of Halych-Volhynia]] churches in a traditional Kievan style were built for some time, but eventually the style began to drift towards Central European Romanesque tradition.
llm_output:
Changed the thumbnail size of images related to St. Sofia in Kiev and the Church of the Intercession on the Nerl from 200px to 300px.

Not Weaponised. The change is purely a formatting adjustment for image display and does not alter the content or introduce any weaponised narratives.

Its austere thick walls, small narrow windows, and helmeted cupolas have much in common with the [[Romanesque architecture]] of Western Europe.

initial_version:
Architecture in [[Kievan Rus]] dates from the its [[Baptism of Kiev|Christianisation]] in [[988]]. The style of architecture developed soon after greatly influenced by [[Byzantine architecture]] with the main architectural works being [[Orthodox Church| Orthodox]] churches. Early churches were mainly made of wood with the simplest form of church becoming known as a [[cell church]]. Major cathedrals often featured scores of small domes, which led some art historians to take this as an indication of what the pagan Slavic temples should have looked like. [[Image:Nereditsa.jpg|thumb|The city of [[Novgorod]] and its dependencies boast the largest number of pre-Mongolian churches.]]

The [[Church of the Tithes]] was the first prominent building to be made of stone in the 10th century. The earliest [[Kiev]]an churches were built and decorated with [[fresco]]es and [[mosaic]]s by Byzantine masters. A great example of an early Russo-Byzantine church was the 13-domed [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Kiev]] (1037-54) but unfortunately much of its exterior has been altered with time. [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Novgorod]] (1044-52), on the other hand, is a purely Russian structure. Its austere thick walls, small narrow windows, and helmeted cupolas have much in common with the [[Romanesque architecture]] of Western Europe. Even further departure from Byzantine models is evident in succeeding cathedrals of Novgorod: St Nicholas's (1113), St Anthony's (1117-19), and St George's (1119). 

By the end of the [[12th century]] the centre of political life had moved from Kiev to the northern principality of [[Vladimir-Suzdal]]. The local churches were built of white stone by Romanesque masters of [[Friedrich Barbarossa]], whilst their wall statuary was elaborately carved by craftsmen from [[Georgia (Caucasus)|Georgia]]. These churches mark the highest point of pre-[[Mongol invasion of Rus|Mongolian]] Russian architecture. The most important [[Vladimir]] churches are the [[Assumption Cathedral in Vladimir|Assumption Cathedral]] (built 1158-60, enlarged 1185-98, frescoes 1408) and St Demetrios' Cathedral (built 1194-97). Another miraculously preserved church is the graceful [[Intercession Church on the Nerl]] (1165), one of the most charming images of medieval Russia. 

Celebrated as these structures are, the contemporaries were even more impressed by churches of Southern Rus, particularly the Svirskaya Church of [[Smolensk ]](1191-94). As southern structures were either ruined or rebuilt, restoration of their original outlook has been a 
source of contention between art historians. The most memorable reconstruction is the Pyatnitskaya Church in [[Chernigov]] (1196-99), by [[Peter Baranovsky]].

Secular architecture of [[Kievan Rus]] is scarcely known. Up to the 20th century, only the [[Golden Gate (Vladimir)|Golden Gates]] of [[Vladimir]], despite much 18th-century restoration, could be regarded as an authentic monument of pre-Mongolian period. In the 1940s, the archaeologist [[Nikolai Voronin]] discovered the well-preserved remains of [[Andrei Bogolyubsky]]'s palace in [[Bogolyubovo]], dating from 1158-65.
changed_version:

+++ 
@@ -1,3 +1,4 @@
+[[File:VNovgorog SaintSophiaCathedral VN130.jpg|thumb|[[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Novgorod|Saint Sophia Cathedral]] in [[Veliky Novgorod]] (1045—1050)]]
 The medieval state of '''[[Kievan Rus']]''' incorporated parts of what is now modern [[Ukraine]], [[Russia]], and [[Belarus]], and was centered on [[Kiev]] and [[Novgorod]]. Its '''architectural style''' quickly established itself after the [[Baptism of Kievan Rus'|adoption of Christianity]] in 988 and was strongly influenced by the [[Byzantine architecture|Byzantine]]. After the disintegration of [[Kievan Rus']] followed by [[Mongol invasion of Rus|Mongol invasion]] in the first half of the 13th century, the architectural tradition continued in the principalities of [[Novgorod Republic|Novgorod]], [[Vladimir-Suzdal]], [[Galicia-Volhynia]] and eventually had direct influence on the [[Russian architecture|Russian]], [[Ukrainian architecture|Ukrainian]], and [[Belarusian architecture|Belarusian]] Architecture.
 
 ==Church architecture==

The earliest [[Kiev]]an churches were built and decorated with [[fresco]]es and [[mosaic]]s by Byzantine masters. A great example of an early Russo-Byzantine church was the 13-domed [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Kiev]] (1037-54) but unfortunately much of its exterior has been altered with time. [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Novgorod]] (1044-52), on the other hand, is a purely Russian structure. Its austere thick walls, small narrow windows, and helmeted cupolas have much in common with the [[Romanesque architecture]] of Western Europe. Even further departure from Byzantine models is evident in succeeding cathedrals of Novgorod: St Nicholas's (1113), St Anthony's (1117-19), and St George's (1119). 

By the end of the [[12th century]] the centre of political life had moved from Kiev to the northern principality of [[Vladimir-Suzdal]]. The local churches were built of white stone by Romanesque masters of [[Friedrich Barbarossa]], whilst their wall statuary was elaborately carved by craftsmen from [[Georgia (Caucasus)|Georgia]]. These churches mark the highest point of pre-[[Mongol invasion of Rus|Mongolian]] Russian architecture. The most important [[Vladimir]] churches are the [[Assumption Cathedral in Vladimir|Assumption Cathedral]] (built 1158-60, enlarged 1185-98, frescoes 1408) and St Demetrios' Cathedral (built 1194-97). Another miraculously preserved church is the graceful [[Intercession Church on the Nerl]] (1165), one of the most charming images of medieval Russia. 

Celebrated as these structures are, the contemporaries were even more impressed by churches of Southern Rus, particularly the Svirskaya Church of [[Smolensk ]](1191-94). As southern structures were either ruined or rebuilt, restoration of their original outlook has been a 
source of contention between art historians. The most memorable reconstruction is the Pyatnitskaya Church in [[Chernigov]] (1196-99), by [[Peter Baranovsky]].

Secular architecture of [[Kievan Rus]] is scarcely known. Up to the 20th century, only the [[Golden Gate (Vladimir)|Golden Gates]] of [[Vladimir]], despite much 18th-century restoration, could be regarded as an authentic monument of pre-Mongolian period. In the 1940s, the archaeologist [[Nikolai Voronin]] discovered the well-preserved remains of [[Andrei Bogolyubsky]]'s palace in [[Bogolyubovo]], dating from 1158-65.

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -18,7 +18,7 @@
 
 Along with cathedrals, of note was the architecture of monasteries of these times.
 
-The 12th-13th centuries were the period of feudal division of Kievan Rus into princedoms which were in nearly permanent feud, with multiplication of cathedrals in emerging princedoms and courts of local princes ''[[knyaz]]es''.
+The 12th-13th centuries were the period of feudal division of Kievan Rus into princedoms which were in nearly permanent feud, with multiplication of cathedrals in emerging princedoms and courts of local princes (''[[knyaz]]es'').
 
 [[File:Church_of_the_Protection_of_the_Theotokos_on_the_Nerl_05.jpg|thumb|300px|[[Church of the Intercession on the Nerl]] (1165), one of the most famous Russian medieval churches.]]
 By the end of the 12th century the divide of the country was final and new centers of power took the Kievan style and adopted it to their traditions. In the northern principality of [[Vladimir-Suzdal]] the local churches were built of white stone with help of Romanesque masters of [[Friedrich Barbarossa]], whilst their wall statuary was elaborately carved by craftsmen from [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]].{{Citation needed|date=May 2008}} The Suzdal style is also known as "white-stone architecture" ("белокаменное зодчество"). The first white-stone church was the [[St. Boris and Gleb Church]] commissioned by [[Yuri Dolgoruky]], a church-fortress in [[Kideksha]] near Suzdal, at the supposed place of the stay of knyazes Boris and Gleb on their pilgrimage to Kiev. The white-stone churches mark the highest point of pre-[[Mongol invasion of Rus|Mongolian]] Rus' architecture. The most important churches in [[Vladimir, Russia|Vladimir]] are the [[Assumption Cathedral in Vladimir|Assumption Cathedral]] (built 1158-60, enlarged 1185-98, frescoes 1408) and [[St Demetrios Cathedral]] (built 1194-97).

Another miraculously preserved church is the graceful [[Intercession Church on the Nerl]] (1165), one of the most charming images of medieval Russia. 

Celebrated as these structures are, the contemporaries were even more impressed by churches of Southern Rus, particularly the Svirskaya Church of [[Smolensk ]](1191-94). As southern structures were either ruined or rebuilt, restoration of their original outlook has been a 
source of contention between art historians. The most memorable reconstruction is the Pyatnitskaya Church in [[Chernigov]] (1196-99), by [[Peter Baranovsky]].

Secular architecture of [[Kievan Rus]] is scarcely known. Up to the 20th century, only the [[Golden Gate (Vladimir)|Golden Gates]] of [[Vladimir]], despite much 18th-century restoration, could be regarded as an authentic monument of pre-Mongolian period. In the 1940s, the archaeologist [[Nikolai Voronin]] discovered the well-preserved remains of [[Andrei Bogolyubsky]]'s palace in [[Bogolyubovo]], dating from 1158-65.

initial_version:
Architecture in [[Kievan Rus]] dates from the its [[Baptism of Kiev|Christianisation]] in [[988]]. The style of architecture developed soon after greatly influenced by [[Byzantine architecture]] with the main architectural works being [[Orthodox Church| Orthodox]] churches. Early churches were mainly made of wood with the simplest form of church becoming known as a [[cell church]]. Major cathedrals often featured scores of small domes, which led some art historians to take this as an indication of what the pagan Slavic temples should have looked like. [[Image:Nereditsa.jpg|thumb|The city of [[Novgorod]] and its dependencies boast the largest number of pre-Mongolian churches.]]

The [[Church of the Tithes]] was the first prominent building to be made of stone in the 10th century. The earliest [[Kiev]]an churches were built and decorated with [[fresco]]es and [[mosaic]]s by Byzantine masters. A great example of an early Russo-Byzantine church was the 13-domed [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Kiev]] (1037-54) but unfortunately much of its exterior has been altered with time. [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Novgorod]] (1044-52), on the other hand, is a purely Russian structure. Its austere thick walls, small narrow windows, and helmeted cupolas have much in common with the [[Romanesque architecture]] of Western Europe. Even further departure from Byzantine models is evident in succeeding cathedrals of Novgorod: St Nicholas's (1113), St Anthony's (1117-19), and St George's (1119). 

By the end of the [[12th century]] the centre of political life had moved from Kiev to the northern principality of [[Vladimir-Suzdal]]. The local churches were built of white stone by Romanesque masters of [[Friedrich Barbarossa]], whilst their wall statuary was elaborately carved by craftsmen from [[Georgia (Caucasus)|Georgia]]. These churches mark the highest point of pre-[[Mongol invasion of Rus|Mongolian]] Russian architecture. The most important [[Vladimir]] churches are the [[Assumption Cathedral in Vladimir|Assumption Cathedral]] (built 1158-60, enlarged 1185-98, frescoes 1408) and St Demetrios' Cathedral (built 1194-97). Another miraculously preserved church is the graceful [[Intercession Church on the Nerl]] (1165), one of the most charming images of medieval Russia. 

Celebrated as these structures are, the contemporaries were even more impressed by churches of Southern Rus, particularly the Svirskaya Church of [[Smolensk ]](1191-94). As southern structures were either ruined or rebuilt, restoration of their original outlook has been a 
source of contention between art historians. The most memorable reconstruction is the Pyatnitskaya Church in [[Chernigov]] (1196-99), by [[Peter Baranovsky]].

Secular architecture of [[Kievan Rus]] is scarcely known. Up to the 20th century, only the [[Golden Gate (Vladimir)|Golden Gates]] of [[Vladimir]], despite much 18th-century restoration, could be regarded as an authentic monument of pre-Mongolian period. In the 1940s, the archaeologist [[Nikolai Voronin]] discovered the well-preserved remains of [[Andrei Bogolyubsky]]'s palace in [[Bogolyubovo]], dating from 1158-65.

The architectural style of the Kievan state, which quickly established itself, was strongly influenced by [[Byzantine architecture]].  The medieval state of [[Kievan Rus']] incorporated parts of what is now modern [[Ukraine]], [[Russia]], and [[Belarus]], and was centered on [[Kiev]] and [[Novgorod]]. Its architecture is the earliest period of [[Russian architecture]], with a style that quickly established itself after the [[Baptism of Kievan Rus'|adoption of Christianity]] in 988 and was strongly influenced by [[Byzantine architecture]]. 
 
 After the disintegration of Kievan Rus' followed by [[Mongol invasion of Rus|Mongol invasion]] in the first half of the 13th century, the architectural tradition continued in the principalities of [[Novgorod Republic|Novgorod]], [[Vladimir-Suzdal]], [[Galicia-Volhynia]] and eventually had direct influence on the [[Russian architecture|Russian]], [[Ukrainian architecture|Ukrainian]], and [[Belarus|Belarusian]] architecture.
 
 ==Church architecture==
-[[File:Maket Sofii.JPG|thumb|300px|Before its reconstruction in the 18th century, St. Sofia in Kiev was a prime example and a model for all churches in Kievan Rus]]
+[[File:Maket Sofii.JPG|thumb|Before its reconstruction in the 18th century, St. Sofia in Kiev was a prime example and a model for all churches in Kievan Rus]]

The architectural style of the Kievan state which quickly established itself was strongly influenced by the [[Byzantine architecture|Byzantine]]. Early [[Eastern Orthodox]] churches were mainly made of wood with the simplest form of church becoming known as a [[cell church]]. Major cathedrals often featured scores of small domes, which led some art historians to take this as an indication of what the pagan Slavic temples should have looked like.
 
@@ -20,7 +20,7 @@
 
 The 12th-13th centuries were the period of feudal division of Kievan Rus into princedoms which were in nearly permanent feud, with multiplication of cathedrals in emerging princedoms and courts of local princes (''[[knyaz]]es'').
 
-[[File:Church_of_the_Protection_of_the_Theotokos_on_the_Nerl_05.jpg|thumb|300px|[[Church of the Intercession on the Nerl]] (1165), one of the most famous Russian medieval churches.]]
+[[File:Church_of_the_Protection_of_the_Theotokos_on_the_Nerl_05.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Church of the Intercession on the Nerl]] (1165), one of the most famous Russian medieval churches.]]
 By the end of the 12th century the divide of the country was final and new centers of power took the Kievan style and adopted it to their traditions. In the northern principality of [[Vladimir-Suzdal]] the local churches were built of white stone with help of Romanesque masters of [[Friedrich Barbarossa]], whilst their wall statuary was elaborately carved by craftsmen from [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]].{{Citation needed|date=May 2008}} The Suzdal style is also known as "white-stone architecture" ("белокаменное зодчество"). The first white-stone church was the [[St. Boris and Gleb Church]] commissioned by [[Yuri Dolgoruky]], a church-fortress in [[Kideksha]] near Suzdal, at the supposed place of the stay of knyazes Boris and Gleb on their pilgrimage to Kiev. The white-stone churches mark the highest point of pre-[[Mongol invasion of Rus|Mongolian]] Rus' architecture. The most important churches in [[Vladimir, Russia|Vladimir]] are the [[Assumption Cathedral in Vladimir|Assumption Cathedral]] (built 1158-60, enlarged 1185-98, frescoes 1408) and [[St Demetrios Cathedral]] (built 1194-97).
 
 In the western splinter of [[Kingdom of Halych-Volhynia]] churches in a traditional Kievan style were built for some time, but eventually the style began to drift towards Central European Romanesque tradition.

initial_version:
Architecture in [[Kievan Rus]] dates from the its [[Baptism of Kiev|Christianisation]] in [[988]]. The style of architecture developed soon after greatly influenced by [[Byzantine architecture]] with the main architectural works being [[Orthodox Church| Orthodox]] churches. Early churches were mainly made of wood with the simplest form of church becoming known as a [[cell church]]. Major cathedrals often featured scores of small domes, which led some art historians to take this as an indication of what the pagan Slavic temples should have looked like. [[Image:Nereditsa.jpg|thumb|The city of [[Novgorod]] and its dependencies boast the largest number of pre-Mongolian churches.]]

The [[Church of the Tithes]] was the first prominent building to be made of stone in the 10th century. The earliest [[Kiev]]an churches were built and decorated with [[fresco]]es and [[mosaic]]s by Byzantine masters. A great example of an early Russo-Byzantine church was the 13-domed [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Kiev]] (1037-54) but unfortunately much of its exterior has been altered with time. [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Novgorod]] (1044-52), on the other hand, is a purely Russian structure. Its austere thick walls, small narrow windows, and helmeted cupolas have much in common with the [[Romanesque architecture]] of Western Europe. Even further departure from Byzantine models is evident in succeeding cathedrals of Novgorod: St Nicholas's (1113), St Anthony's (1117-19), and St George's (1119). 

By the end of the [[12th century]] the centre of political life had moved from Kiev to the northern principality of [[Vladimir-Suzdal]]. The local churches were built of white stone by Romanesque masters of [[Friedrich Barbarossa]], whilst their wall statuary was elaborately carved by craftsmen from [[Georgia (Caucasus)|Georgia]]. These churches mark the highest point of pre-[[Mongol invasion of Rus|Mongolian]] Russian architecture. The most important [[Vladimir]] churches are the [[Assumption Cathedral in Vladimir|Assumption Cathedral]] (built 1158-60, enlarged 1185-98, frescoes 1408) and St Demetrios' Cathedral (built 1194-97). Another miraculously preserved church is the graceful [[Intercession Church on the Nerl]] (1165), one of the most charming images of medieval Russia. 

Celebrated as these structures are, the contemporaries were even more impressed by churches of Southern Rus, particularly the Svirskaya Church of [[Smolensk ]](1191-94). As southern structures were either ruined or rebuilt, restoration of their original outlook has been a 
source of contention between art historians. The most memorable reconstruction is the Pyatnitskaya Church in [[Chernigov]] (1196-99), by [[Peter Baranovsky]].

Secular architecture of [[Kievan Rus]] is scarcely known. Up to the 20th century, only the [[Golden Gate (Vladimir)|Golden Gates]] of [[Vladimir]], despite much 18th-century restoration, could be regarded as an authentic monument of pre-Mongolian period. In the 1940s, the archaeologist [[Nikolai Voronin]] discovered the well-preserved remains of [[Andrei Bogolyubsky]]'s palace in [[Bogolyubovo]], dating from 1158-65.

Architecture in [[Kievan Rus]] dates from the its [[Baptism of Kiev|Christianisation]] in [[988]]. The style of architecture developed soon after greatly influenced by [[Byzantine architecture]] with the main architectural works being [[Orthodox Church| Orthodox]] churches. Early churches were mainly made of wood with the simplest form of church becoming known as a [[cell church]]. Major cathedrals often featured scores of small domes, which led some art historians to take this as an indication of what the pagan Slavic temples should have looked like. [[Image:Nereditsa.jpg|thumb|The city of [[Novgorod]] and its dependencies boast the largest number of pre-Mongolian churches.]]

The [[Church of the Tithes]] was the first prominent building to be made of stone in the 10th century. The earliest [[Kiev]]an churches were built and decorated with [[fresco]]es and [[mosaic]]s by Byzantine masters. A great example of an early Russo-Byzantine church was the 13-domed [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Kiev]] (1037-54) but unfortunately much of its exterior has been altered with time. [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Novgorod]] (1044-52), on the other hand, is a purely Russian structure. Its austere thick walls, small narrow windows, and helmeted cupolas have much in common with the [[Romanesque architecture]] of Western Europe. Even further departure from Byzantine models is evident in succeeding cathedrals of Novgorod: St Nicholas's (1113), St Anthony's (1117-19), and St George's (1119). 

By the end of the [[12th century]] the centre of political life had moved from Kiev to the northern principality of [[Vladimir-Suzdal]]. The local churches were built of white stone by Romanesque masters of [[Friedrich Barbarossa]], whilst their wall statuary was elaborately carved by craftsmen from [[Georgia (Caucasus)|Georgia]]. These churches mark the highest point of pre-[[Mongol invasion of Rus|Mongolian]] Russian architecture. The most important [[Vladimir]] churches are the [[Assumption Cathedral in Vladimir|Assumption Cathedral]] (built 1158-60, enlarged 1185-98, frescoes 1408) and St Demetrios' Cathedral (built 1194-97). Another miraculously preserved church is the graceful [[Intercession Church on the Nerl]] (1165), one of the most charming images of medieval Russia. 

Celebrated as these structures are, the contemporaries were even more impressed by churches of Southern Rus, particularly the Svirskaya Church of [[Smolensk ]](1191-94). As southern structures were either ruined or rebuilt, restoration of their original outlook has been a 
source of contention between art historians. The most memorable reconstruction is the Pyatnitskaya Church in [[Chernigov]] (1196-99), by [[Peter Baranovsky]].

Secular architecture of [[Kievan Rus]] is scarcely known. Up to the 20th century, only the [[Golden Gate (Vladimir)|Golden Gates]] of [[Vladimir]], despite much 18th-century restoration, could be regarded as an authentic monument of pre-Mongolian period. In the 1940s, the archaeologist [[Nikolai Voronin]] discovered the well-preserved remains of [[Andrei Bogolyubsky]]'s palace in [[Bogolyubovo]], dating from 1158-65.

@@ -1,7 +1,7 @@
 [[File:VNovgorog SaintSophiaCathedral VN130.jpg|thumb|[[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Novgorod|Saint Sophia Cathedral]] in [[Veliky Novgorod]] (1045—1050)]]
 The medieval state of [[Kievan Rus']] incorporated parts of what is now modern [[Ukraine]], [[Russia]], and [[Belarus]], and was centered on [[Kiev]] and [[Novgorod]]. Its architecture is the earliest period of [[Russian architecture]], with a style that quickly established itself after the [[Baptism of Kievan Rus'|adoption of Christianity]] in 988 and was strongly influenced by [[Byzantine architecture]]. 
 
-After the disintegration of [[Kievan Rus']] followed by [[Mongol invasion of Rus|Mongol invasion]] in the first half of the 13th century, the architectural tradition continued in the principalities of [[Novgorod Republic|Novgorod]], [[Vladimir-Suzdal]], [[Galicia-Volhynia]] and eventually had direct influence on the [[Russian architecture|Russian]], [[Ukrainian architecture|Ukrainian]], and [[Belarusian architecture|Belarusian]] Architecture.
+After the disintegration of Kievan Rus' followed by [[Mongol invasion of Rus|Mongol invasion]] in the first half of the 13th century, the architectural tradition continued in the principalities of [[Novgorod Republic|Novgorod]], [[Vladimir-Suzdal]], [[Galicia-Volhynia]] and eventually had direct influence on the [[Russian architecture|Russian]], [[Ukrainian architecture|Ukrainian]], and [[Belarusian architecture|Belarusian]] Architecture.

In the northern principality of [[Vladimir-Suzdal]] the local churches were built of white stone with help of Romanesque masters of [[Friedrich Barbarossa]], whilst their wall statuary was elaborately carved by craftsmen from [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]].{{Citation needed|date=May 2008}} The Suzdal style is also known as "white-stone architecture" ("белокаменное зодчество"). The first white-stone church was the [[St. Boris and Gleb Church]] commissioned by [[Yuri Dolgoruky]], a church-fortress in [[Kideksha]] near Suzdal, at the supposed place of the stay of knyazes Boris and Gleb on their pilgrimage to Kiev. The white-stone churches mark the highest point of pre-[[Mongol invasion of Rus|Mongolian]] Rus' architecture. The most important churches in [[Vladimir, Russia|Vladimir]] are the [[Assumption Cathedral in Vladimir|Assumption Cathedral]] (built 1158-60, enlarged 1185-98, frescoes 1408) and [[St Demetrios Cathedral]] (built 1194-97).
+By the end of the 12th century, the divide of the country was final and new centers of power took the Kievan style and adopted it to their traditions. In the northern principality of [[Vladimir-Suzdal]] the local churches were built of white stone with the help of [[Friedrich Barbarossa]]'s Romanesque masters, whilst their wall statuary was elaborately carved by craftsmen from [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]].{{Citation needed|date=May 2008}} The Suzdal style is also known as "white-stone architecture" ("белокаменное зодчество"). The first white-stone church was the [[St. Boris and Gleb Church]] commissioned by [[Yuri Dolgoruky]], a church-fortress in [[Kideksha]] near Suzdal, at the supposed place of the stay of knyazes Boris and Gleb on their pilgrimage to Kiev. The white-stone churches mark the highest point of pre-[[Mongol invasion of Rus|Mongolian]] Rus' architecture. The most important churches in [[Vladimir, Russia|Vladimir]] are the [[Assumption Cathedral in Vladimir|Assumption Cathedral]] (built 1158–60, enlarged 1185–98, frescoes 1408) and [[St Demetrios Cathedral]] (built 1194–97).
 
 In the western splinter of [[Kingdom of Halych-Volhynia]] churches in a traditional Kievan style were built for some time, but eventually the style began to drift towards Central European Romanesque tradition.

initial_version:
Architecture in [[Kievan Rus]] dates from the its [[Baptism of Kiev|Christianisation]] in [[988]]. The style of architecture developed soon after greatly influenced by [[Byzantine architecture]] with the main architectural works being [[Orthodox Church| Orthodox]] churches. Early churches were mainly made of wood with the simplest form of church becoming known as a [[cell church]]. Major cathedrals often featured scores of small domes, which led some art historians to take this as an indication of what the pagan Slavic temples should have looked like. [[Image:Nereditsa.jpg|thumb|The city of [[Novgorod]] and its dependencies boast the largest number of pre-Mongolian churches.]]

The [[Church of the Tithes]] was the first prominent building to be made of stone in the 10th century. The earliest [[Kiev]]an churches were built and decorated with [[fresco]]es and [[mosaic]]s by Byzantine masters. A great example of an early Russo-Byzantine church was the 13-domed [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Kiev]] (1037-54) but unfortunately much of its exterior has been altered with time. [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Novgorod]] (1044-52), on the other hand, is a purely Russian structure. Its austere thick walls, small narrow windows, and helmeted cupolas have much in common with the [[Romanesque architecture]] of Western Europe. Even further departure from Byzantine models is evident in succeeding cathedrals of Novgorod: St Nicholas's (1113), St Anthony's (1117-19), and St George's (1119). 

By the end of the [[12th century]] the centre of political life had moved from Kiev to the northern principality of [[Vladimir-Suzdal]]. The local churches were built of white stone by Romanesque masters of [[Friedrich Barbarossa]], whilst their wall statuary was elaborately carved by craftsmen from [[Georgia (Caucasus)|Georgia]]. These churches mark the highest point of pre-[[Mongol invasion of Rus|Mongolian]] Russian architecture. The most important [[Vladimir]] churches are the [[Assumption Cathedral in Vladimir|Assumption Cathedral]] (built 1158-60, enlarged 1185-98, frescoes 1408) and St Demetrios' Cathedral (built 1194-97). Another miraculously preserved church is the graceful [[Intercession Church on the Nerl]] (1165), one of the most charming images of medieval Russia. 

Celebrated as these structures are, the contemporaries were even more impressed by churches of Southern Rus, particularly the Svirskaya Church of [[Smolensk ]](1191-94). As southern structures were either ruined or rebuilt, restoration of their original outlook has been a 
source of contention between art historians. The most memorable reconstruction is the Pyatnitskaya Church in [[Chernigov]] (1196-99), by [[Peter Baranovsky]].

Secular architecture of [[Kievan Rus]] is scarcely known. Up to the 20th century, only the [[Golden Gate (Vladimir)|Golden Gates]] of [[Vladimir]], despite much 18th-century restoration, could be regarded as an authentic monument of pre-Mongolian period. In the 1940s, the archaeologist [[Nikolai Voronin]] discovered the well-preserved remains of [[Andrei Bogolyubsky]]'s palace in [[Bogolyubovo]], dating from 1158-65.

-The medieval state of [[Kievan Rus']] incorporated parts of what is now modern [[Ukraine]], [[Russia]], and [[Belarus]], and was centered on [[Kiev]] and [[Novgorod]]. Its architecture is the earliest period of [[Russian architecture]], with a style that quickly established itself after the [[Baptism of Kievan Rus'|adoption of Christianity]] in 988 and was strongly influenced by [[Byzantine architecture]]. 
+The medieval state of [[Kievan Rus']] incorporated parts of what is now modern [[Ukraine]], [[Russia]], and [[Belarus]], and was centered on [[Kyiv]] and [[Novgorod]]. Its architecture is the earliest period of [[Russian architecture]], with a style that quickly established itself after the [[Baptism of Kievan Rus'|adoption of Christianity]] in 988 and was strongly influenced by [[Byzantine architecture]]. 
 
 After the disintegration of Kievan Rus' followed by [[Mongol invasion of Rus|Mongol invasion]] in the first half of the 13th century, the architectural tradition continued in the principalities of [[Novgorod Republic|Novgorod]], [[Vladimir-Suzdal]], [[Galicia-Volhynia]] and eventually had direct influence on the [[Russian architecture|Russian]], [[Ukrainian architecture|Ukrainian]], and [[Belarus|Belarusian]] architecture.

initial_version:
Architecture in [[Kievan Rus]] dates from the its [[Baptism of Kiev|Christianisation]] in [[988]]. The style of architecture developed soon after greatly influenced by [[Byzantine architecture]] with the main architectural works being [[Orthodox Church| Orthodox]] churches. Early churches were mainly made of wood with the simplest form of church becoming known as a [[cell church]]. Major cathedrals often featured scores of small domes, which led some art historians to take this as an indication of what the pagan Slavic temples should have looked like. [[Image:Nereditsa.jpg|thumb|The city of [[Novgorod]] and its dependencies boast the largest number of pre-Mongolian churches.]]

The [[Church of the Tithes]] was the first prominent building to be made of stone in the 10th century. The earliest [[Kiev]]an churches were built and decorated with [[fresco]]es and [[mosaic]]s by Byzantine masters. A great example of an early Russo-Byzantine church was the 13-domed [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Kiev]] (1037-54) but unfortunately much of its exterior has been altered with time. [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Novgorod]] (1044-52), on the other hand, is a purely Russian structure. Its austere thick walls, small narrow windows, and helmeted cupolas have much in common with the [[Romanesque architecture]] of Western Europe. Even further departure from Byzantine models is evident in succeeding cathedrals of Novgorod: St Nicholas's (1113), St Anthony's (1117-19), and St George's (1119). 

By the end of the [[12th century]] the centre of political life had moved from Kiev to the northern principality of [[Vladimir-Suzdal]]. The local churches were built of white stone by Romanesque masters of [[Friedrich Barbarossa]], whilst their wall statuary was elaborately carved by craftsmen from [[Georgia (Caucasus)|Georgia]]. These churches mark the highest point of pre-[[Mongol invasion of Rus|Mongolian]] Russian architecture. The most important [[Vladimir]] churches are the [[Assumption Cathedral in Vladimir|Assumption Cathedral]] (built 1158-60, enlarged 1185-98, frescoes 1408) and St Demetrios' Cathedral (built 1194-97). Another miraculously preserved church is the graceful [[Intercession Church on the Nerl]] (1165), one of the most charming images of medieval Russia. 

Celebrated as these structures are, the contemporaries were even more impressed by churches of Southern Rus, particularly the Svirskaya Church of [[Smolensk ]](1191-94). As southern structures were either ruined or rebuilt, restoration of their original outlook has been a 
source of contention between art historians. The most memorable reconstruction is the Pyatnitskaya Church in [[Chernigov]] (1196-99), by [[Peter Baranovsky]].

Secular architecture of [[Kievan Rus]] is scarcely known. Up to the 20th century, only the [[Golden Gate (Vladimir)|Golden Gates]] of [[Vladimir]], despite much 18th-century restoration, could be regarded as an authentic monument of pre-Mongolian period. In the 1940s, the archaeologist [[Nikolai Voronin]] discovered the well-preserved remains of [[Andrei Bogolyubsky]]'s palace in [[Bogolyubovo]], dating from 1158-65.
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -1,4 +1,4 @@
-'''''Bold text'''''[[File:VNovgorog SaintSophiaCathedral VN130.jpg|thumb|260px|[[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Novgorod|Saint Sophia Cathedral]] in [[Veliky Novgorod]] (1045–1050)]]
+[[File:VNovgorog SaintSophiaCathedral VN130.jpg|thumb|260px|[[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Novgorod|Saint Sophia Cathedral]] in [[Veliky Novgorod]] (1045–1050)]]
 The medieval state of [[Kievan Rus']] incorporated parts of what is now modern [[Ukraine]], [[Russia]], and [[Belarus]], and was centered on [[Kiev]] and [[Novgorod]]. Its architecture is the earliest period of [[Russian architecture]], with a style that quickly established itself after the [[Baptism of Kievan Rus'|adoption of Christianity]] in 988 and was strongly influenced by [[Byzantine architecture]]. 
 
 After the disintegration of Kievan Rus' followed by [[Mongol invasion of Rus|Mongol invasion]] in the first half of the 13th century, the architectural tradition continued in the principalities of [[Novgorod Republic|Novgorod]], [[Vladimir-Suzdal]], [[Galicia-Volhynia]] and eventually had direct influence on the [[Russian architecture|Russian]], [[Ukrainian architecture|Ukrainian]], and [[Belarus|Belarusian]] architecture.
llm_output:
Removed "'''''Bold text'''''". 

Not Weaponised. The change is a simple formatting adjustment without any ideological implications or shifts in narrative.

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -26,9 +26,9 @@
 Celebrated as these structures are, the contemporaries were even more impressed by churches of Southern Rus', particularly the [[Svirskaya Church]] of [[Smolensk]] (1191–94). As southern structures were either ruined or rebuilt, restoration of their original outlook has been a source of contention between art historians. The most memorable reconstruction is the Pyatnitskaya Church (1196–99) in [[Chernigov]] (modern Chernihiv, Ukraine), by [[Peter Baranovsky]].
 
 ==Secular architecture==
-There were very few examples of secular (non-religious) architecture in [[Kievan Rus]]. [[Golden Gate (Vladimir)|Golden Gates]] of [[Vladimir, Russia|Vladimir]], despite much 18th-century restoration, could be regarded as an authentic monument of the pre-Mongolian period.
+There were very few examples of secular (non-religious) architecture in [[Kievan Rus|Kyivan Rus’]]. [[Golden Gate (Vladimir)|Golden Gates]] of [[Vladimir, Russia|Vladimir]], despite much 18th-century restoration, could be regarded as an authentic monument of the pre-Mongolian period.
 
-In Kyiv, the capital of the country, no secular monuments survived aside from pieces of walls and ruins of gates. The [[Golden Gates of Kyiv]] were destroyed completely over the years with only the ruins remaining. In the 20th century a museum was erected above the ruins, it is mirror image of the gates of the Kievan Rus period but is not a monument of the time.
+In Kyiv, the capital of the country, no secular monuments survived aside from pieces of walls and ruins of gates. The [[Golden Gate, Kyiv|Golden Gates of Kyiv]] were destroyed completely over the years with only the ruins remaining. In the 20th century a museum was erected above the ruins, it is mirror image of the gates of the Kyivan Rus’ period but is not a monument of the time.
 
 One of the best examples, the fortress of [[Bilhorod Kyivskyi]], is still lying under the ground waiting major excavation.  In the 1940s, the archaeologist [[Nikolai Voronin]] discovered the well-preserved remains of [[Andrei Bogolyubsky]]'s palace in [[Bogolyubovo]], dating from 1158–65.
llm_output:
The change made is a rephrasing of "Kievan Rus" to "Kyivan Rus’" and "Golden Gates of Kyiv" to "Golden Gate, Kyiv". 

Not Weaponised. The changes appear to be focused on standardizing the naming conventions without introducing any politically charged language or narratives.

initial_version:
Architecture in [[Kievan Rus]] dates from the its [[Baptism of Kiev|Christianisation]] in [[988]]. The style of architecture developed soon after greatly influenced by [[Byzantine architecture]] with the main architectural works being [[Orthodox Church| Orthodox]] churches. Early churches were mainly made of wood with the simplest form of church becoming known as a [[cell church]]. Major cathedrals often featured scores of small domes, which led some art historians to take this as an indication of what the pagan Slavic temples should have looked like. [[Image:Nereditsa.jpg|thumb|The city of [[Novgorod]] and its dependencies boast the largest number of pre-Mongolian churches.]]

The [[Church of the Tithes]] was the first prominent building to be made of stone in the 10th century. The earliest [[Kiev]]an churches were built and decorated with [[fresco]]es and [[mosaic]]s by Byzantine masters. A great example of an early Russo-Byzantine church was the 13-domed [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Kiev]] (1037-54) but unfortunately much of its exterior has been altered with time. [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Novgorod]] (1044-52), on the other hand, is a purely Russian structure. Its austere thick walls, small narrow windows, and helmeted cupolas have much in common with the [[Romanesque architecture]] of Western Europe. Even further departure from Byzantine models is evident in succeeding cathedrals of Novgorod: St Nicholas's (1113), St Anthony's (1117-19), and St George's (1119). 

By the end of the [[12th century]] the centre of political life had moved from Kiev to the northern principality of [[Vladimir-Suzdal]]. The local churches were built of white stone by Romanesque masters of [[Friedrich Barbarossa]], whilst their wall statuary was elaborately carved by craftsmen from [[Georgia (Caucasus)|Georgia]]. These churches mark the highest point of pre-[[Mongol invasion of Rus|Mongolian]] Russian architecture. The most important [[Vladimir]] churches are the [[Assumption Cathedral in Vladimir|Assumption Cathedral]] (built 1158-60, enlarged 1185-98, frescoes 1408) and St Demetrios' Cathedral (built 1194-97). Another miraculously preserved church is the graceful [[Intercession Church on the Nerl]] (1165), one of the most charming images of medieval Russia. 

Celebrated as these structures are, the contemporaries were even more impressed by churches of Southern Rus, particularly the Svirskaya Church of [[Smolensk ]](1191-94). As southern structures were either ruined or rebuilt, restoration of their original outlook has been a 
source of contention between art historians. The most memorable reconstruction is the Pyatnitskaya Church in [[Chernigov]] (1196-99), by [[Peter Baranovsky]].

Secular architecture of [[Kievan Rus]] is scarcely known. Up to the 20th century, only the [[Golden Gate (Vladimir)|Golden Gates]] of [[Vladimir]], despite much 18th-century restoration, could be regarded as an authentic monument of pre-Mongolian period. In the 1940s, the archaeologist [[Nikolai Voronin]] discovered the well-preserved remains of [[Andrei Bogolyubsky]]'s palace in [[Bogolyubovo]], dating from 1158-65.

This style had a great influence on the entire architecture of ancient Russia, including the structure and decoration of [[Russian Orthodox Church|churches]] and the art of [[icon painting]].

 The medieval state of [[Kievan Rus']] incorporated parts of what is now modern [[Ukraine]], [[Russia]], and [[Belarus]], and was centered on [[Kiev]] and [[Novgorod]]. Its architecture is the earliest period of [[Russian architecture]], using the foundations of Byzantine culture but with great use of innovations and architectural features.

[[Image:Nereditsa.jpg|thumb|The city of [[Novgorod]] and its dependencies boast the largest number of pre-Mongolian churches.]]

The [[Church of the Tithes]] was the first prominent building to be made of stone in the 10th century. The earliest [[Kiev]]an churches were built and decorated with [[fresco]]es and [[mosaic]]s by Byzantine masters. A great example of an early Russo-Byzantine church was the 13-domed [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Kiev]] (1037-54) but unfortunately much of its exterior has been altered with time. [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Novgorod]] (1044-52), on the other hand, is a purely Russian structure. Its austere thick walls, small narrow windows, and helmeted cupolas have much in common with the [[Romanesque architecture]] of Western Europe. Even further departure from Byzantine models is evident in succeeding cathedrals of Novgorod: St Nicholas's (1113), St Anthony's (1117-19), and St George's (1119). 

By the end of the [[12th century]] the centre of political life had moved from Kiev to the northern principality of [[Vladimir-Suzdal]]. The local churches were built of white stone by Romanesque masters of [[Friedrich Barbarossa]], whilst their wall statuary was elaborately carved by craftsmen from [[Georgia (Caucasus)|Georgia]]. These churches mark the highest point of pre-[[Mongol invasion of Rus|Mongolian]] Russian architecture. The most important [[Vladimir]] churches are the [[Assumption Cathedral in Vladimir|Assumption Cathedral]] (built 1158-60, enlarged 1185-98, frescoes 1408) and St Demetrios' Cathedral (built 1194-97). Another miraculously preserved church is the graceful [[Intercession Church on the Nerl]] (1165), one of the most charming images of medieval Russia. 

Celebrated as these structures are, the contemporaries were even more impressed by churches of Southern Rus, particularly the Svirskaya Church of [[Smolensk ]](1191-94). As southern structures were either ruined or rebuilt, restoration of their original outlook has been a 
source of contention between art historians. The most memorable reconstruction is the Pyatnitskaya Church in [[Chernigov]] (1196-99), by [[Peter Baranovsky]].

Secular architecture of [[Kievan Rus]] is scarcely known. Up to the 20th century, only the [[Golden Gate (Vladimir)|Golden Gates]] of [[Vladimir]], despite much 18th-century restoration, could be regarded as an authentic monument of pre-Mongolian period. In the 1940s, the archaeologist [[Nikolai Voronin]] discovered the well-preserved remains of [[Andrei Bogolyubsky]]'s palace in [[Bogolyubovo]], dating from 1158-65.

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -20,7 +20,7 @@
 
 The 12th-13th centuries were the period of feudal division of Kievan Rus into princedoms which were in nearly permanent feud, with multipication of cathedrals in emerging princedoms and courts of local princes ''[[knyaz]]es''.
 
-[[File:Bogolyubovo.jpg|thumb|300px|[[Church of the Intercession on the Nerl]] (1165), one of the most famous Russian medieval churches.]]
+[[File:Church_of_the_Protection_of_the_Theotokos_on_the_Nerl_05.jpg|thumb|300px|[[Church of the Intercession on the Nerl]] (1165), one of the most famous Russian medieval churches.]]
 By the end of the 12th century the divide of the country was final and new centers of power took the Kievan style and adopted it to their traditions. In the northern principality of [[Vladimir-Suzdal]] the local churches were built of white stone with help of Romanesque masters of [[Friedrich Barbarossa]], whilst their wall statuary was elaborately carved by craftsmen from [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]].{{Citation needed|date=May 2008}} The Suzdal style is also known as "white-stone architecture" ("белокаменное зодчество"). The first white-stone church was the [[St. Boris and Gleb Church]] commissioned by [[Yuri Dolgoruky]], a church-fortress in [[Kideksha]] near Suzdal, at the supposed place of the stay of knyazes Boris and Gleb on their pilgrimage to Kiev. The white-stone churches mark the highest point of pre-[[Mongol invasion of Rus|Mongolian]] Rus' architecture. The most important churches in [[Vladimir, Russia|Vladimir]] are the [[Assumption Cathedral in Vladimir|Assumption Cathedral]] (built 1158-60, enlarged 1185-98, frescoes 1408) and [[St Demetrios Cathedral]] (built 1194-97).
 
 In the western splinter of [[Kingdom of Halych-Volhynia]] churches in a traditional Kievan style were built for some time, but eventually the style began to drift towards Central European Romanesque tradition.
@@ -45,7 +45,6 @@
 File:Собор Успения Пресвятой Богородицы XII века постройки.jpg|[[Assumption Cathedral, Staraya Ladoga]] (1154-1159)

initial_version:
Architecture in [[Kievan Rus]] dates from the its [[Baptism of Kiev|Christianisation]] in [[988]]. The style of architecture developed soon after greatly influenced by [[Byzantine architecture]] with the main architectural works being [[Orthodox Church| Orthodox]] churches. Early churches were mainly made of wood with the simplest form of church becoming known as a [[cell church]]. Major cathedrals often featured scores of small domes, which led some art historians to take this as an indication of what the pagan Slavic temples should have looked like. [[Image:Nereditsa.jpg|thumb|The city of [[Novgorod]] and its dependencies boast the largest number of pre-Mongolian churches.]]

The [[Church of the Tithes]] was the first prominent building to be made of stone in the 10th century. The earliest [[Kiev]]an churches were built and decorated with [[fresco]]es and [[mosaic]]s by Byzantine masters. A great example of an early Russo-Byzantine church was the 13-domed [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Kiev]] (1037-54) but unfortunately much of its exterior has been altered with time. [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Novgorod]] (1044-52), on the other hand, is a purely Russian structure. Its austere thick walls, small narrow windows, and helmeted cupolas have much in common with the [[Romanesque architecture]] of Western Europe. Even further departure from Byzantine models is evident in succeeding cathedrals of Novgorod: St Nicholas's (1113), St Anthony's (1117-19), and St George's (1119). 

By the end of the [[12th century]] the centre of political life had moved from Kiev to the northern principality of [[Vladimir-Suzdal]]. The local churches were built of white stone by Romanesque masters of [[Friedrich Barbarossa]], whilst their wall statuary was elaborately carved by craftsmen from [[Georgia (Caucasus)|Georgia]]. These churches mark the highest point of pre-[[Mongol invasion of Rus|Mongolian]] Russian architecture. The most important [[Vladimir]] churches are the [[Assumption Cathedral in Vladimir|Assumption Cathedral]] (built 1158-60, enlarged 1185-98, frescoes 1408) and St Demetrios' Cathedral (built 1194-97). Another miraculously preserved church is the graceful [[Intercession Church on the Nerl]] (1165), one of the most charming images of medieval Russia. 

Celebrated as these structures are, the contemporaries were even more impressed by churches of Southern Rus, particularly the Svirskaya Church of [[Smolensk ]](1191-94). As southern structures were either ruined or rebuilt, restoration of their original outlook has been a 
source of contention between art historians. The most memorable reconstruction is the Pyatnitskaya Church in [[Chernigov]] (1196-99), by [[Peter Baranovsky]].

Secular architecture of [[Kievan Rus]] is scarcely known. Up to the 20th century, only the [[Golden Gate (Vladimir)|Golden Gates]] of [[Vladimir]], despite much 18th-century restoration, could be regarded as an authentic monument of pre-Mongolian period. In the 1940s, the archaeologist [[Nikolai Voronin]] discovered the well-preserved remains of [[Andrei Bogolyubsky]]'s palace in [[Bogolyubovo]], dating from 1158-65.

Its austere thick walls, small narrow windows, and helmeted cupolas have much in common with the [[Romanesque architecture]] of Western Europe.

+Even further departure from Byzantine models is evident in succeeding cathedrals of Novgorod: St Nicholas's (1113), St Anthony's (1117–19), and St George's (1119).  Along with cathedrals, of note was the architecture of monasteries of these times.  The 12th–13th centuries were the period of feudal division of Kievan Rus into princedoms which were in nearly permanent feud, with multiplication of cathedrals in emerging princedoms and courts of local princes (''[[knyaz]]es'').
 
 [[File:Church_of_the_Protection_of_the_Theotokos_on_the_Nerl_05.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Church of the Intercession on the Nerl]] (1165), one of the most famous Russian medieval churches.]]
 By the end of the 12th century, the divide of the country was final and new centers of power took the Kievan style and adopted it to their traditions. In the northern principality of [[Vladimir-Suzdal]] the local churches were built of white stone with the help of [[Friedrich Barbarossa]]'s Romanesque masters, whilst their wall statuary was elaborately carved by craftsmen from [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]].{{Citation needed|date=May 2008}} The Suzdal style is also known as "white-stone architecture" ("белокаменное зодчество"). The first white-stone church was the [[St. Boris and Gleb Church]] commissioned by [[Yuri Dolgoruky]], a church-fortress in [[Kideksha]] near Suzdal, at the supposed place of the stay of knyazes Boris and Gleb on their pilgrimage to Kiev. The white-stone churches mark the highest point of pre-[[Mongol invasion of Rus|Mongolian]] Rus' architecture. The most important churches in [[Vladimir, Russia|Vladimir]] are the [[Assumption Cathedral in Vladimir|Assumption Cathedral]] (built 1158–60, enlarged 1185–98, frescoes 1408) and [[St Demetrios Cathedral]] (built 1194–97).

initial_version:
Architecture in [[Kievan Rus]] dates from the its [[Baptism of Kiev|Christianisation]] in [[988]]. The style of architecture developed soon after greatly influenced by [[Byzantine architecture]] with the main architectural works being [[Orthodox Church| Orthodox]] churches. Early churches were mainly made of wood with the simplest form of church becoming known as a [[cell church]]. Major cathedrals often featured scores of small domes, which led some art historians to take this as an indication of what the pagan Slavic temples should have looked like. [[Image:Nereditsa.jpg|thumb|The city of [[Novgorod]] and its dependencies boast the largest number of pre-Mongolian churches.]]

The [[Church of the Tithes]] was the first prominent building to be made of stone in the 10th century. The earliest [[Kiev]]an churches were built and decorated with [[fresco]]es and [[mosaic]]s by Byzantine masters. A great example of an early Russo-Byzantine church was the 13-domed [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Kiev]] (1037-54) but unfortunately much of its exterior has been altered with time. [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Novgorod]] (1044-52), on the other hand, is a purely Russian structure. Its austere thick walls, small narrow windows, and helmeted cupolas have much in common with the [[Romanesque architecture]] of Western Europe. Even further departure from Byzantine models is evident in succeeding cathedrals of Novgorod: St Nicholas's (1113), St Anthony's (1117-19), and St George's (1119). 

By the end of the [[12th century]] the centre of political life had moved from Kiev to the northern principality of [[Vladimir-Suzdal]]. The local churches were built of white stone by Romanesque masters of [[Friedrich Barbarossa]], whilst their wall statuary was elaborately carved by craftsmen from [[Georgia (Caucasus)|Georgia]]. These churches mark the highest point of pre-[[Mongol invasion of Rus|Mongolian]] Russian architecture. The most important [[Vladimir]] churches are the [[Assumption Cathedral in Vladimir|Assumption Cathedral]] (built 1158-60, enlarged 1185-98, frescoes 1408) and St Demetrios' Cathedral (built 1194-97). Another miraculously preserved church is the graceful [[Intercession Church on the Nerl]] (1165), one of the most charming images of medieval Russia. 

Celebrated as these structures are, the contemporaries were even more impressed by churches of Southern Rus, particularly the Svirskaya Church of [[Smolensk ]](1191-94). As southern structures were either ruined or rebuilt, restoration of their original outlook has been a 
source of contention between art historians. The most memorable reconstruction is the Pyatnitskaya Church in [[Chernigov]] (1196-99), by [[Peter Baranovsky]].

Secular architecture of [[Kievan Rus]] is scarcely known. Up to the 20th century, only the [[Golden Gate (Vladimir)|Golden Gates]] of [[Vladimir]], despite much 18th-century restoration, could be regarded as an authentic monument of pre-Mongolian period. In the 1940s, the archaeologist [[Nikolai Voronin]] discovered the well-preserved remains of [[Andrei Bogolyubsky]]'s palace in [[Bogolyubovo]], dating from 1158-65.

Its architecture is the earliest period of [[Russian architecture]], using the foundations of Byzantine culture but with great use of innovations and architectural features. Most remains are  [[Russian Orthodox Church|[Russian Orthodox churches]].
+The '''architecture of Kievan Rus'''' comes from the medieval state of [[Kievan Rus']] incorporated parts of what is now modern [[Ukraine]], [[Russia]], and [[Belarus]], and was centered on [[Kiev]] and [[Novgorod]]. Its architecture is the earliest period of [[Russian architecture]], using the foundations of Byzantine culture but with great use of innovations and architectural features. Most remains are [[Russian Orthodox Church|Russian Orthodox churches]].
 
 After the disintegration of Kievan Rus' followed by [[Mongol invasion of Rus|Mongol invasion]] in the first half of the 13th century, the architectural tradition continued in the principalities of [[Novgorod Republic|Novgorod]], [[Vladimir-Suzdal]], [[Galicia-Volhynia]] and eventually had direct influence on the [[Russian architecture|Russian]], [[Ukrainian architecture|Ukrainian]], and [[Belarus|Belarusian]] architecture. The Old Russian architecture of churches originates from the pre-Christian Slavic "''zodching''" ({{lang-ru|Зодчество|italic=yes}} - construction).

@@ -3,7 +3,7 @@
 
 The '''architecture of Kievan Rus'''' comes from the medieval state of [[Kievan Rus']] which incorporated parts of what is now modern [[Ukraine]], [[Russia]], and [[Belarus]], and was centered on [[Kiev]] and [[Novgorod]]. Its architecture is the earliest period of [[Russian architecture]], using the foundations of Byzantine culture but with great use of innovations and architectural features. Most remains are [[Russian Orthodox Church|Russian Orthodox churches]] or parts of the gates and fortifications of cities.
 
-After the disintegration of Kievan Rus' followed by [[Mongol invasion of Rus|Mongol invasion]] in the first half of the 13th century, the architectural tradition continued in the principalities of [[Novgorod Republic|Novgorod]], [[Vladimir-Suzdal]], [[Galicia-Volhynia]] and eventually had direct influence on the [[Russian architecture|Russian]], [[Ukrainian architecture|Ukrainian]], and [[Belarus|Belarusian]] architecture. The Old Russian architecture of churches originates from the pre-Christian Slavic "''zodching''" ({{lang-ru|Зодчество|italic=yes}} - construction).
+After the disintegration of Kievan Rus' followed by [[Mongol invasion of Rus|Mongol invasion]] in the first half of the 13th century, the architectural tradition continued in the principalities of [[Novgorod Republic|Novgorod]], [[Vladimir-Suzdal]], [[Galicia-Volhynia]] and eventually had direct influence on the [[Russian architecture|Russian]], [[Ukrainian architecture|Ukrainian]], and [[Belarus|Belarusian]] architecture. The Old Russian architecture of churches originates from the pre-Christian Slavic "''zodching''" ({{lang-ru|Зодчество|italic=yes}} - construction). A map of well preserved Kievan Rus' architecture may be found [https://www.google.com/maps/d/u/0/edit?mid=1jy5tcP06o4-H-E4Y6Mh197tohd4V7CME&usp=sharing here.]
 
 ==Church architecture==
 [[File:Софійський собор 43.jpg|thumb|Before its reconstruction in the 18th century, St. Sofia in Kiev was a prime example and a model for all churches in Kievan Rus]]

initial_version:
Architecture in [[Kievan Rus]] dates from the its [[Baptism of Kiev|Christianisation]] in [[988]]. The style of architecture developed soon after greatly influenced by [[Byzantine architecture]] with the main architectural works being [[Orthodox Church| Orthodox]] churches. Early churches were mainly made of wood with the simplest form of church becoming known as a [[cell church]]. Major cathedrals often featured scores of small domes, which led some art historians to take this as an indication of what the pagan Slavic temples should have looked like. [[Image:Nereditsa.jpg|thumb|The city of [[Novgorod]] and its dependencies boast the largest number of pre-Mongolian churches.]]

The [[Church of the Tithes]] was the first prominent building to be made of stone in the 10th century. The earliest [[Kiev]]an churches were built and decorated with [[fresco]]es and [[mosaic]]s by Byzantine masters. A great example of an early Russo-Byzantine church was the 13-domed [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Kiev]] (1037-54) but unfortunately much of its exterior has been altered with time. [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Novgorod]] (1044-52), on the other hand, is a purely Russian structure. Its austere thick walls, small narrow windows, and helmeted cupolas have much in common with the [[Romanesque architecture]] of Western Europe. Even further departure from Byzantine models is evident in succeeding cathedrals of Novgorod: St Nicholas's (1113), St Anthony's (1117-19), and St George's (1119). 

By the end of the [[12th century]] the centre of political life had moved from Kiev to the northern principality of [[Vladimir-Suzdal]]. The local churches were built of white stone by Romanesque masters of [[Friedrich Barbarossa]], whilst their wall statuary was elaborately carved by craftsmen from [[Georgia (Caucasus)|Georgia]]. These churches mark the highest point of pre-[[Mongol invasion of Rus|Mongolian]] Russian architecture. The most important [[Vladimir]] churches are the [[Assumption Cathedral in Vladimir|Assumption Cathedral]] (built 1158-60, enlarged 1185-98, frescoes 1408) and St Demetrios' Cathedral (built 1194-97). Another miraculously preserved church is the graceful [[Intercession Church on the Nerl]] (1165), one of the most charming images of medieval Russia. 

Celebrated as these structures are, the contemporaries were even more impressed by churches of Southern Rus, particularly the Svirskaya Church of [[Smolensk ]](1191-94). As southern structures were either ruined or rebuilt, restoration of their original outlook has been a 
source of contention between art historians. The most memorable reconstruction is the Pyatnitskaya Church in [[Chernigov]] (1196-99), by [[Peter Baranovsky]].

Secular architecture of [[Kievan Rus]] is scarcely known. Up to the 20th century, only the [[Golden Gate (Vladimir)|Golden Gates]] of [[Vladimir]], despite much 18th-century restoration, could be regarded as an authentic monument of pre-Mongolian period. In the 1940s, the archaeologist [[Nikolai Voronin]] discovered the well-preserved remains of [[Andrei Bogolyubsky]]'s palace in [[Bogolyubovo]], dating from 1158-65.

@@ -28,7 +28,7 @@
 
 In [[Kyiv]], the capital of [[Ukraine]], no secular monuments survived aside from pieces of walls and ruins of gates. The [[Golden Gate, Kyiv|Golden Gates of Kyiv]] were destroyed completely over the years with only the ruins remaining. initial_version:
Architecture in [[Kievan Rus]] dates from the its [[Baptism of Kiev|Christianisation]] in [[988]]. The style of architecture developed soon after greatly influenced by [[Byzantine architecture]] with the main architectural works being [[Orthodox Church| Orthodox]] churches. Early churches were mainly made of wood with the simplest form of church becoming known as a [[cell church]]. Major cathedrals often featured scores of small domes, which led some art historians to take this as an indication of what the pagan Slavic temples should have looked like. [[Image:Nereditsa.jpg|thumb|The city of [[Novgorod]] and its dependencies boast the largest number of pre-Mongolian churches.]]

The [[Church of the Tithes]] was the first prominent building to be made of stone in the 10th century. The earliest [[Kiev]]an churches were built and decorated with [[fresco]]es and [[mosaic]]s by Byzantine masters. A great example of an early Russo-Byzantine church was the 13-domed [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Kiev]] (1037-54) but unfortunately much of its exterior has been altered with time. [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Novgorod]] (1044-52), on the other hand, is a purely Russian structure. Its austere thick walls, small narrow windows, and helmeted cupolas have much in common with the [[Romanesque architecture]] of Western Europe. Even further departure from Byzantine models is evident in succeeding cathedrals of Novgorod: St Nicholas's (1113), St Anthony's (1117-19), and St George's (1119). 

By the end of the [[12th century]] the centre of political life had moved from Kiev to the northern principality of [[Vladimir-Suzdal]]. The local churches were built of white stone by Romanesque masters of [[Friedrich Barbarossa]], whilst their wall statuary was elaborately carved by craftsmen from [[Georgia (Caucasus)|Georgia]]. These churches mark the highest point of pre-[[Mongol invasion of Rus|Mongolian]] Russian architecture. The most important [[Vladimir]] churches are the [[Assumption Cathedral in Vladimir|Assumption Cathedral]] (built 1158-60, enlarged 1185-98, frescoes 1408) and St Demetrios' Cathedral (built 1194-97). Another miraculously preserved church is the graceful [[Intercession Church on the Nerl]] (1165), one of the most charming images of medieval Russia. 

Celebrated as these structures are, the contemporaries were even more impressed by churches of Southern Rus, particularly the Svirskaya Church of [[Smolensk ]](1191-94). As southern structures were either ruined or rebuilt, restoration of their original outlook has been a 
source of contention between art historians. The most memorable reconstruction is the Pyatnitskaya Church in [[Chernigov]] (1196-99), by [[Peter Baranovsky]].

Secular architecture of [[Kievan Rus]] is scarcely known. Up to the 20th century, only the [[Golden Gate (Vladimir)|Golden Gates]] of [[Vladimir]], despite much 18th-century restoration, could be regarded as an authentic monument of pre-Mongolian period. In the 1940s, the archaeologist [[Nikolai Voronin]] discovered the well-preserved remains of [[Andrei Bogolyubsky]]'s palace in [[Bogolyubovo]], dating from 1158-65.
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -17,7 +17,7 @@
 Even further departure from Byzantine models is evident in succeeding cathedrals of Novgorod: St Nicholas's (1113), St Anthony's (1117–19), and St George's (1119).  Along with cathedrals, of note was the architecture of monasteries of these times.  The 12th–13th centuries were the period of feudal division of Kievan Rus into princedoms which were in nearly permanent feud, with multiplication of cathedrals in emerging princedoms and courts of local princes (''[[knyaz]]es'').
 
 [[File:Church_of_the_Protection_of_the_Theotokos_on_the_Nerl_05.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Church of the Intercession on the Nerl]] (1165), one of the most famous Russian medieval churches.]]
-By the end of the 12th century, the divide of the country was final and new centers of power took the Kievan style and adopted it to their traditions. In the northern principality of [[Vladimir-Suzdal]] the local churches were built of white stone with the help of [[Friedrich Barbarossa]]'s Romanesque masters, whilst their wall statuary was elaborately carved by craftsmen from [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]].{{Citation needed|date=May 2008}} The Suzdal style is also known as "white-stone architecture" ("белокаменное зодчество"). The first white-stone church was the [[St. Boris and Gleb Church]] commissioned by [[Yuri Dolgoruky]], a church-fortress in [[Kideksha]] near Suzdal, at the supposed place of the stay of knyazes Boris and Gleb on their pilgrimage to Kiev. The white-stone churches mark the highest point of pre-[[Mongol invasion of Rus|Mongolian]] Rus' architecture. The most important churches in [[Vladimir, Russia|Vladimir]] are the [[Assumption Cathedral in Vladimir|Assumption Cathedral]] (built 1158–60, enlarged 1185–98, frescoes 1408) and [[St Demetrios Cathedral]] (built 1194–97).
+By the end of the 12th century, the divide of the country was final and new centers of power took the Kievan style and adopted it to their traditions. In the northern principality of [[Vladimir-Suzdal]] the local churches were built of white stone. The Suzdal style is also known as "white-stone architecture" ("белокаменное зодчество"). The first white-stone church was the [[St. Boris and Gleb Church]] commissioned by [[Yuri Dolgoruky]], a church-fortress in [[Kideksha]] near Suzdal, at the supposed place of the stay of knyazes Boris and Gleb on their pilgrimage to Kiev. The white-stone churches mark the highest point of pre-[[Mongol invasion of Rus|Mongolian]] Rus' architecture. The most important churches in [[Vladimir, Russia|Vladimir]] are the [[Assumption Cathedral in Vladimir|Assumption Cathedral]] (built 1158–60, enlarged 1185–98, frescoes 1408) and [[St Demetrios Cathedral]] (built 1194–97).
 
 In the western splinter of [[Kingdom of Halych-Volhynia]] churches in a traditional Kievan style were built for some time, but eventually the style began to drift towards Central European Romanesque tradition.
comment: /* Church architecture */  Friedrich Barbarossa lived in the 11th century, not in the 12th. And i can’t find anything about Georgian masters in Google.

initial_version:
Architecture in [[Kievan Rus]] dates from the its [[Baptism of Kiev|Christianisation]] in [[988]]. The style of architecture developed soon after greatly influenced by [[Byzantine architecture]] with the main architectural works being [[Orthodox Church| Orthodox]] churches. Early churches were mainly made of wood with the simplest form of church becoming known as a [[cell church]]. Major cathedrals often featured scores of small domes, which led some art historians to take this as an indication of what the pagan Slavic temples should have looked like. [[Image:Nereditsa.jpg|thumb|The city of [[Novgorod]] and its dependencies boast the largest number of pre-Mongolian churches.]]

The [[Church of the Tithes]] was the first prominent building to be made of stone in the 10th century. The earliest [[Kiev]]an churches were built and decorated with [[fresco]]es and [[mosaic]]s by Byzantine masters. A great example of an early Russo-Byzantine church was the 13-domed [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Kiev]] (1037-54) but unfortunately much of its exterior has been altered with time. [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Novgorod]] (1044-52), on the other hand, is a purely Russian structure. Its austere thick walls, small narrow windows, and helmeted cupolas have much in common with the [[Romanesque architecture]] of Western Europe. Even further departure from Byzantine models is evident in succeeding cathedrals of Novgorod: St Nicholas's (1113), St Anthony's (1117-19), and St George's (1119). 

By the end of the [[12th century]] the centre of political life had moved from Kiev to the northern principality of [[Vladimir-Suzdal]]. The local churches were built of white stone by Romanesque masters of [[Friedrich Barbarossa]], whilst their wall statuary was elaborately carved by craftsmen from [[Georgia (Caucasus)|Georgia]]. These churches mark the highest point of pre-[[Mongol invasion of Rus|Mongolian]] Russian architecture. The most important [[Vladimir]] churches are the [[Assumption Cathedral in Vladimir|Assumption Cathedral]] (built 1158-60, enlarged 1185-98, frescoes 1408) and St Demetrios' Cathedral (built 1194-97). Another miraculously preserved church is the graceful [[Intercession Church on the Nerl]] (1165), one of the most charming images of medieval Russia. 

Celebrated as these structures are, the contemporaries were even more impressed by churches of Southern Rus, particularly the Svirskaya Church of [[Smolensk ]](1191-94). As southern structures were either ruined or rebuilt, restoration of their original outlook has been a 
source of contention between art historians. The most memorable reconstruction is the Pyatnitskaya Church in [[Chernigov]] (1196-99), by [[Peter Baranovsky]].

Secular architecture of [[Kievan Rus]] is scarcely known. Up to the 20th century, only the [[Golden Gate (Vladimir)|Golden Gates]] of [[Vladimir]], despite much 18th-century restoration, could be regarded as an authentic monument of pre-Mongolian period. In the 1940s, the archaeologist [[Nikolai Voronin]] discovered the well-preserved remains of [[Andrei Bogolyubsky]]'s palace in [[Bogolyubovo]], dating from 1158-65.
